comment.author: 25752562@N07
comment._content: The Kasr el-Nil Bridge, completed in 1933 to cross the Nile River, in central Cairo.

comment.author: 91271949@N00
comment._content: Funny, KAsr el-Nil nowadays looks different, although the lions still stand...

comment.author: 25752562@N07
comment._content: The pedestals look different. Perhaps they were changed when the bridge was widened?

comment.author: 91271949@N00
comment._content: Are these the same lyons? It looks like the lyons on the picture have less space between the legs than the ones in your comment.

comment.author: 91271949@N00
comment._content: the bridge reminded me more of Abu 'l ela (or something like that) from Zamalek to Bulaaq... with the iron sides...

comment.author: 91271949@N00
comment._content: The picture here shows the Kasr al Nil bridge before 1931: www.egy.com/zamalek/00-11-01.shtml

comment.author: 25752562@N07
comment._content: Fascinating – thank you for sharing this!

comment.author: 26651465@N06
comment._content: This is the old bridge established Khedive Ismail Pacha in the last third of nineteenth century and was renovated by the early 1930's as mentioned above.  They are the same lions but different angles of shots

comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content: All great information, thanks for sharing!

comment.author: 19199747@N00
comment._content: KH1954 is correct. This pic was taken circa 1870s/1880s.

comment.author: 8661413@N02
comment._content: The Qasr El Nil bridge was built between 1931 and 1933, on the same location as the Gezira bridge built in 1872 by Khedive Ismail, the lions are the works of late 19th century French sculptor and animalier Henri Alfred Jacquemart., they were put there somewhere closer to 1880.
